awd_titl_txt: Fundamental controls on mid-crustal 'escape' flow in orogenic systems
awd_abstract_narration:
In large mountain belts that result from continent-continent collision, the tremendous accumulation of rock mass that creates the high mountainous topography must be removed from the system by a variety of mechanisms. In the shallow crust, this is mostly accomplished by the erosive action of rivers and glaciers. At greater depths the middle and lower crust can be weakened by partial melting and then may flow out of the collision zone in a process known as channel or escape flow. In the Himalayan-Tibetan system, it has been proposed that crustal escape flow dominates deformation in the lower crust beneath the eastern Tibetan margin and may even contribute to slip and seismicity along upper crustal strike-slip faults in northeastern India, northern Myanmar, and southern China. Understanding if these crustal escape flows are truly present and how they operate in large mountain belt systems remains as a fundamental challenge for tectonics research, particularly because they cannot be directly observed at depth. Critical to our understanding of how escape flow may operate is the nature of the boundaries that direct such flow and how they dynamically interact with the channel system, so ideally a study of this type should be carried out by examining a crustal channel that has had its upper crustal 'lid' removed. This project is examining a possible crustal escape flow system that is exposed at the surface in the southern Appalachian Inner Piedmont of North Carolina, South Carolina, and Georgia. In addition, this work is producing a critical suite of geochronologic and petrotectonic analyses for a classic eastern U.S. field area that lacks much of this basic data. This project contributes to the advancement of desired societal outcomes by supporting advanced field and laboratory training for a graduate student in an important science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM discipline), and is providing support for an early career investigator. Most importantly, this project will also support research training and collaboration experience for at least six undergraduate researchers under the guidance of the principal investigator.

Although the classic channel flow model quite elegantly explains a number of seemingly unrelated features in the Himalayan system, the condition(s) that may have led to deactivation and/or redirection of the channel at the southern front of the Tibetan Plateau remains as a persistent enigma for this model. Specifically, it is necessary to understand: (1) what conditions or mechanistic changes might lead to a switch from an orogen-normal channel flow dominated system to one that accommodates shortening by critical wedge-style slip along major thrusts at the front of an orogen, (2) could the same conditions(s) and mechanisms be responsible for a switch to orogen-parallel escape flow in large hot orogens that undergo this transition, and (3) what is the nature of the boundaries that direct such flow and how do they dynamically interact with the orogen-parallel channel system? To do this, it was necessary to identify a potential channel system now exposed at the surface. In the southern Appalachian Inner Piedmont, previous studies proposed the presence of a Neoacadian (Devonian-Mississippian) crustal escape flow system based on the observation of a map scale curved lineation pattern and preservation of an extensive area of pervasive migmatization, sillimanite I-II metamorphism, and numerous anatectic plutons. This study is addressing the questions above in the Inner Piedmont using integrated metamorphic and structural petrology, chemical diffusion modeling, and geo- (monazite and titanite laser ablation split stream technique) and thermochronology (40Ar/39Ar hornblende and muscovite) combined with paleopiezometry and quartz fabric-derived deformation temperatures to establish Pressure-Temperature-temperature-stress paths and system residence times for representative structural levels across the interpreted channel system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Models that explain how continents collide evolved from simple wedge geometries built-up by faults and crustal thickening to more complex ideas involving long distance flow of weak crustal material out of the collision zone. In modern tectonics, many of these models derived from the Himalayan collision zone, wherein Indian continental crust is pushed beneath the southern margin of Asia without subducting. Although much progress has been made, testing these models in large mountain belt systems like the Himalayas remains as a fundamental challenge for tectonics research, particularly because they cannot be directly observed at depth. The primary goal of this project was to use the southern Appalachian Blue Ridge and Inner Piedmont, which has been interpreted by some researchers as a paleo-Himalayan-Tibetan system, to test these ideas of continent-continent collision. The fundamental processes that govern fault geometry, deformation spatial extent, intensity, and timing, and the development of metamorphism and melting in these systems act as first order controls on earthquake occurrence and magnitude, mineral resource accumulation and distribution, the occurrence and distribution of deformation fabrics that act to weaken surface rock exposures (e.g., fractures and foliations), and development of topography and drainage systems, among other things.

 

In the southern Appalachians, characterizing these processes has remained as a persistent challenge, as this region experienced four major mountain building (orogenic) events in the from 550-280 million years ago, with at least two of those events resulting from major continent-continent collision. During the course of this research, our team was able to complete all of our major objectives, including: (1) coupling pre-existing data with abundant new analyses from this project to constrain most of the spatial extent and intensity of Taconic and Neoacadian orogenic metamorphism in the northern half of the southern Appalachians, which provided a key framework for testing models of continent-continent collision, (2) used mid- to low-T thermochronology to establish the minimum age and distribution of these metamorphic events, and (3) developed models of stress across the major fault boundaries between the Blue Ridge and Inner Piedmont, which helps us to understand the development of both stress and strain across the major fault boundaries during continental collision.

 

A secondary albeit strategically important accomplishment for this work was the establishment of a framework bedrock critical mineral assessment in the southern Appalachians. Critical minerals, named for their importance to U.S. strategic initiatives relating to energy, defense, and technology, are considered those minerals that have a high risk of supply chain disruption. Many of these minerals, known as rare earth materials, concentrate in areas with high amounts of metamorphism and igneous activity driven by orogenic events such as those studied in this project.  This region, which yields some of the highest Ce, La, and other heavy rare earth assays according to the N.U.R.E. assessment, we now know to be derived from metamorphic monazite produced during the Taconic, Neoacadian, and Alleghanian orogenic events. Our campaign style of geo- and thermochronology employed in this region, which previously had limited analyses, allows us to characterize the source terranes of these critical minerals. Additionally, our detailed characterization of these minerals using the laser ablation split stream technique allows us understand: (a) the spatial distribution and density of these minerals, (b) the dependence of mineral richness and average mineral grainsize that can be expected across the range of highly varied southern Appalachian lithologies, (c) the rare-earth volume and composition of these minerals, and (d) perhaps most importantly, the watersheds the drain source terranes and may produce rich placer deposits of these strategically critical minerals.

 

This research also represents progress toward meeting three of the five current grand challenges in tectonics, as identified in the 2018 community vision document, to include understanding variations in lithospheric rheology, understanding fault behavior throughout the lithosphere, and developing synergies between meeting societal needs and advancing tectonics research. Finally, Student training with an emphasis on STEM workforce development has a been considerable component of this project. To date, this project has produced 1 completed Ph.D. degree, I completed M.S. degree, and advanced laboratory research and field training for at least three undergraduates.
